awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Mathematics at Indiana University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the continuation of the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site in the Department of Mathematics at Indiana University, Bloomington. Preserving a valued tradition dating back nearly fifty years, the program will offer an intensive summer research experience for talented undergraduates working with some of our internationally recognized faculty on unique projects. By providing a well-balanced and structured environment together with milestones for both oral exposition and written reports of results, the IU REU lays the groundwork for student success in their projects. Participant success is further encouraged by the fostering of an intense and collaborative work environment, and most importantly through the regular working sessions with mentors. In addition to the abstract problem solving skills and intellectual stamina gained by the participants, their professional development is enhanced through regular research presentations by faculty members, LaTeX writing workshops, tours and demonstrations of Indiana University's libraries and extensive computational resources which are made available to participants, and other similar opportunities.
 
The Indiana University REU program provides an immersive environment with a strong mentorship oriented approach to research. Eight students will work one-on-one or in small groups with faculty members, spending eight weeks on IU campus tackling carefully selected research problems. Typically, these problems are unsolved, accessible, and mathematically significant. Topics in pure mathematics are chosen from a broad swath of fields including: geometric group theory, differential geometry, combinatorial topology and knot theory, surgery theory, logic, complex and symbolic dynamics, aspects of category theory and several more. Topics in applied mathematics are drawn from areas in computer science such as recursion theory or homotopy type theory and areas of mathematical biology and chemistry from polymer organization and cell function to phylogenetics. Housed together in a dormitory and sharing common office space, students benefit from being immersed in mathematics collectively and from the spontaneous collaboration that naturally follows. Students disseminate their findings by delivering presentations at a statewide undergraduate mathematics research conference, giving formal lectures to peers, faculty, and graduate students, and writing a formal self-contained research report detailing their findings. Some of these reports are expected to develop into peer-reviewed research papers. Ultimately, the program significantly helps prepare participants to be the leaders in today's highly technical workforce, whether in academia or industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The above award funded the summer research experience for undergraduates (REU) in mathematics at Indiana University, Bloomington initially for the three summers 2019-2021 with partial support for 2018. Due to COVID related problems the program did not run in 2021, but through continuing extension support the award instead supported our resurgent summer 2022 program. In each of the three supported summers, 8 undergraduate students were supported on the grant, each being paired with a faculty member on a project. A keystone of our program is nearly one-to-one mentorship and a high level of investment in each student. From our cohort of 24 students during this period we had 12 students mentored by individual faculty, and the remaining 12 in teams of two under the direction of distinct faculty members. The projects themselves spanned a large range of pure and applied topics including probability (percolation, pattern formation in high dimensions, Markov chains, genetic dynamics), quantum invariants (of links, representations, states in polygons), dynamical systems (center manifold reductions, fractal decompositions, entropy estimation), complex analysis over Clifford algebras, conformal dimension of Sierpinski carpets, numerical validation of reduced models, and optimization in game theory.
 
Each year, we recruited a diverse group of students for our program and included significant professional development and training in our program. Each student was given training in LaTeX authoring system and was required to produce a detailed research report of their results and findings. These were then compiled into a book published on our website. Some of these reports later became published papers in peer-reviewed professional mathematics research journals. At the end of the summer, each student presented their work at the Indiana State Undergraduate Mathematical Research Conference. Some students also went on to present their work at national professional conferences. Other development activities included GRE exam preparation and weekly seminars on a breadth of mathematical topics by our faculty at large.  
 
A key broader impact of our program is the equipping and development of future scientists and mathematicians to enter the nation's workforce. We have been able to measure this impact in our most recently graduated cohort from our REU program: over 60% have entered STEM graduate programs and another 15%, at least, have entered the workforce in STEM related fields (most of the remainder we were simply unable track).
